A sundial consists of a flat plate with an elevated fin (gnomon) that casts a shadow to indicate the time of day by the position of the shadow. By aligning the gnomon with the Earth's axis, a sundial can indicate local solar time accurately during the day.

For geographic coordinates, ancient civilizations used systems of meridians and parallels. The concept of latitude was understood since at least the Babylonians, who used it for navigation and mapping. They measured latitude by the angle between the plane of the horizon and the midday sun, effectively measuring the distance north or south of the equator.

The ancient Greeks further developed these ideas. Eratosthenes, for instance, is credited with calculating the circumference of the Earth using simple geometry and the knowledge of the angle difference between two cities due to the curvature of the Earth.
